The Magna Carta, also known as the Great Charter, is a document that King John of England was forced to sign on June 15, 1215. It established certain rights for some Englishmen, especially the barons who were able to force the king to sign it. 

The Magna Carta played a significant role in the development of English law and governance. It served as the cornerstone of English constitutional law and established the principle that everyone, including the king, was subject to the law. 

The Charter also introduced the principle of trial by jury and protected individual rights, such as freedom from arbitrary imprisonment, the right to a fair trial, and protection against excessive fines and taxes. These concepts were critical in the fight for individual liberties, political rights, and constitutional government, which ultimately led to the development of modern Western democracies.

Additionally, the Magna Carta served as a precedent for future documents such as the English Bill of Rights, the American Declaration of Independence, and the United States Constitution. 

In summary, the Magna Carta was a significant historical document because it limited the power of the king, established the principle of the rule of law and individual rights, and served as a foundation for the development of modern constitutional democracies.
